reviewText: A simple, fun, and occasionally frustrating game. Pluses: the art style is adorable, each run is short - success or failure - so it's easy to play in between other things, and the controls are responsive. Minuses: some obstacles are very hard to see, or don't come on screen until you've already committed to a jump to catch more kitties; lack of achievements and leader boards limits the motivation to try and do better. Unless you're into that weird personal improvement" nonsense.\nIn short: more features would be nice
date: but for the price it's an easy recommendation."

reviewText:
This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
Putting kittens into any game is going to instantly get you bonus points, but putting hundreds and hundreds of them into a game is basically a winning combination. Jones on Fire puts you in the shoes of a firefighter saving kittens from the burning blaze throughout a forest.

The gameplay itself is very simple. All you need is one button, the up key. Jones is constantly moving and you cannot stop, you must jump and slide under burning objects, if you miss the jump, the wall of fire catches up to you for a bit until you can gain some ground on it.

After each run through, you get the chance to spend your money, which is in turn granted by how many kittens you save. The rewards consist of straight upgrades, or one time abilities, such as cat nip, which basically attracts all the kittens to you without having to move to collect them.

Each run you get three lives, at the end of the three lives you have to start again, but you don't lose all of your rewards and upgrades, these are carried over. This makes it feel like every run you are improving your character in some way.

This game does the simplicity very well, there looks to be some more content on the way looking at the reward screen as there are two more sections with Coming Soon" showing
date: so it will be interesting to see what else is added.\n\nI can definitely recommend Jones on Fire for the price that is currently set at (£1
hoursPlayed: I have only played for half an hour and I can see myself jumping in again to save a couple hundred more kitties!\n"
voteText: April 19, 2015

reviewText:
Frustrating obstacles past Hazard 9 where the game goes too fast and you cannot pass them no matter how hard you try (ex: wall + slide log). The problem isn't the fact that it goes fast (i like fast games), the problem is that it isn't involving skill, it's involving impossibility. You HAVE to jump to pass the wall, and if you jump, you stub yourself into the logs behind, you can't reach the ground to slide under it, so the level can't be completed unless you are lucky with the layout.

And the game hasn't much to offer, it's just always the same scenery, and an horrible uninspired grind (it takes hours in order to be able to buy an uninspired upgrade)

There are so many better endless runners, free and paying, I can't find the appeal of this one.

reviewText: Jones on Fire is a fun little time-waster with a simple yet engaging mechanic. It's accessible if you're not a superstar gamer, but definitely challenging enough for more advanced gamers (save ALL the kitties!). I played it first on iOS, and I'm delighted to be able to play it on my Mac as well. I haven’t tried setting up a controller yet, but I think that would be an even better way to play (there isn’t native support, but with a little effort it should work).\n\nI also highly recommend the sorta-sequel, Hot Tin Roof.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this adorable game.  This is a runner type gameplay but the levels change up so you cannot just memorize the route.
The sounds are well matched to the game.  The visuals are bright and cartoony but still clear enough that you can easily tell what is going on.
You can play only a few minutes at a time or hours on end if you want.  Trust me you can quickly get addicted and spend an entire afternoon trying to get some more of those precious golden kitties!
If you are looking for a fun way to blow off some steam at the end of a workday (or on a break) this is the game for you.
Plus you wouldn't want to leave those poor kittens in the way of that nasty fire would you?

reviewText: A runner game where you save kittens from a burning forest and get back to base safely. Gets challenging rather quickly, but gets repetitive just as quick. The upgrades and golden kittens just take that long to get and you don't feel like there is much of a goal other than getting to a higher hazard level". Ultimately
date:
It sucks that you need so many golden kitties for higher level temporary boosts (or permanent abilities) so that you can have a proper run - on one level at a time (because the boost wears off after 1 level).

The game often asks you to tweet score for small daily bonuses and each time you press "tweet" it opens a new tab in your browser. I really don't like that. I'd rather get the bonus somehow else.

Edit: Also
hoursPlayed:
your mid-air slides (or even running and falling from top of a obstacle) tend to go too far because there are a lot of obstacles... this can be frustrating and kind of make it really hard to get into hazard 10+

----------------

It's still a fun experience and I recommend giving it a try.

8/!0"

reviewText:
Disclaimer: At the time of writing, most of my experience with this game is from a non-Steam version.

Overall simple and fun. You collect floating kitties while avoiding logs and fire. Collect enough kitties and you can add some more variation to your capabilities. Higher levels have more kitties, and with a higher multiplier when completed. However, if you lose all your lives, you go back to level one. The highest level is 10, and the skill progression can feel a bit slow.

Also, there are slight moments of darkness...why is there a never-ending forest fire and why are there so many cats out there, just floating and spinning in the air?

It's probably better not to ask, just rescue as many as you can.

reviewText:
quick TL;DR version:  I absolutely love this game, buy it!

Jones On Fire is somewhere between a retro platformer and an endless runner.... or... both?!  It's got tight gameplay and controls, a unique (and uniquely suiting) visual aesthetic, and a nice dose of humor and cuteness to boot.

What really makes the game great though, in my humble opinion, is that it essentially hooks you the with the same basic idea of all of the classic OG arcade games -- the game is simple enough for anyone to pick up and play, is easy to grasp, and yet... is VERY hard to play PERFECTLY.  And each time you cause poor lil Jones to be singed nearly to death, you shake your head and SWEAR you won't do that same dumb mistake next time.  I literally think anyone from kids just young enough to hold a controller or use a keyboard, to 31-year-old men (yours truly) and beyond, could enjoy this game equally fully.

Saving cats from fires is so freakin' addictive!  Who knew?!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Timing, timing is everything with this game. So you see a kitty hanging there? You jump to save him/her and come down. Oh no! There was a log! In this game you NEED to pay attention to where you are going and where you will land when jumping.

On the gameplay side of things it's simplistic, but has that old style level runner that a lot of us grew up with as kids. Controls are simble, jump, slide, etc. Doesn't take long to learn them. Especially if you complete the tutorial in the beginning. (I recommend this) You start at hazard level 1, 2hp (Or times you can land in fire or smash into something) before you lose a life. Not to worry! You start with 3, and they appear to regen over time provided you clear a level. When the counter reaches 0, well I'm sure you can guess what happens! It is however a bit hardcore afterward as you drop back to level 1. However, unlike most games that drop you back, you retain all your perks and or upgrades you had purchased previously. This is nice, and certainly helps you continue to climb higher and higher each time you go through runs. Your only objective is simple! You run out there and rescue kitties! And depending how many you rescue, you got it! Determines your over all score for the level and how many points you earn to spend at the actual upgrade stations.


Art style wise it's cute. It's not overly complex, but it doesn't look terrible either. I recommend playing the game to find out! (Music is pretty fun as well but gets slightly repetitive. Thats my personal opinion however!)

All in all I will give this game a 7/10, it did put a smile on my face and I will recommend it to friends and others looking for a decent level runner style of game!

reviewText:
Simplistic, stereotypical, yet, also entertaining.
This game is just super cute in its own little way, analogizing to Jetpack Joyride with its constant fast-paced action game, or Temple Run's classic past-time activity. Or just even compare to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Flappy Bird. It may look like I'm just comparing only somewhat similar games, but what they all have in common is that certain types of feeling you experience while playing the game.
This game seemed to be suited for people who like classic, or even just small-looking Phone games. [Specifically to people who fall for cute kitties!]
Pros:
Fun, time-waster.
Gets more challenging as one progresses, so it doesn't get bland quickly
Kitties! Lots and lots of Kitties for you!
It also appeals to your Pathological emotion, when you lose all of those lives, not being able to save those kitties ahead, you always got infinite second chances, no matter how much you have to walk on flaming logs and slide through flames!
[* Powerups!]

Cons:
I had this on a seperate account, and I remember that:
The only problem I had with this game was 'shortness', this game just needed a few game modes, I mean, once you get all the power ups, [takes a while] and also all the other items, thats where it actually seems to get bland at, because there isn't much to do after that.

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Parkour automatically sidescrolling platform  game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
They give you a tutorial tour if you are new to the game.
You can slide the bar to change the volume to music and the sound.
Music is 8-bitish.
Graphics are pixelated.

About the game.
There are in-game challenges and if you complete them you get some extra points.
You have to save kitties from the fire.
You only have to press the Up arrow key or the down arrow key.
You get points and you could spend them to upgrade your character or the kitties.
White kitties gives white K and golden kitties gives golden K.
The music is decent and it is sort of funky.
You have a health bar and 3 lives. Whenever you ran out of lives then you have to spend Gold K.
If you can't spend golden K to buy lives again. Then you will start all the way back to level 1 again.
Upgrades and challenges will NOT be lost whenever you are restarting back to level 1.
You can recover a health bar by outrunning the fire wall.
Game is very easy to understand and to pickup.
The Parkour will be changed whenever you have died on the level.

Other things.
Jones is a girl...
Mew :3


-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10
